Schmitz]] (brothers), four other siblings and two half-siblings }} '''Mary Kay Fualaau''' (''nÃ©e'' Mary Katherine Schmitz; born January 30, 1962), formerly known as '''Mary Kay Letourneau''', is an American schoolteacher who was imprisoned from 1997 to 2004 for having [[sexual intercourse]] with her 13-year-old student, Vili Fualaau. She gave birth to two of Fualaau's children while incarcerated. After her release from prison in 2004, Letourneau married Fualaau and took his name.{{cite web| first = Kimberly A.C.| last = Wilson| title = Letourneau may be transferred to out-of-state prison| url = http://www.seattlepi.com/local/mary18.shtml| work = Local| publisher = [[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]]| date = March 18, 1999| accessdate = May 11, 2009}}{{cite web| title = Letourneau marries Fualaau amid media circus| url = http://www.seattlepi.com/local/225292_wedding21.html| work = Local| publisher = [[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]]| date = May 21, 2005| accessdate = May 11, 2009}} ==Early life== Letourneau was born '''Mary Katherine Schmitz''' in Tustin, [[California]], to university professor [[John G. Schmitz]] and chemist Mary Schmitz.{{cite web| title = California Births, 1905 - 1995| url=http://www.familytreelegends.com/records/calbirths?c=search&first=Mary&last=Schmitz&spelling=Exact&4_year=&4_month=0&4_day=0&5=&7=&SubmitSearch.x=0&SubmitSearch.y=0| work = Family Tree Legends Records Collection (Online Database)| publisher = Pearl Street Software| year = 2005| accessdate = 2009-05-11}}Warrick, Pamela. [http://articles.latimes.com/1998/apr/29/news/ls-45407?pg=3] She was known as Mary Kay to her family and called "Cake" by her father.{{cite web| title = Mary Kay Letourneau's father dies| url = http://www.seattlepi.com/local/mary12.shtml| work = Local| publisher = [[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]]| date = January 12, 2001| accessdate = May 12, 2009}} She was the fourth of seven children, raised in a "strict Catholic household."Noe, Denise. When she was 2 years old, her father began his political career and successfully ran as a Republican for a seat in the state legislature. He held positions as a [[California state senate|California state senator]] and [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. Congressman]] and, after changing parties, he ran for [[President of the United States|president]] as an [[American Independent Party]] candidate in the [[1972 presidential election|1972 U.S. presidential election]].Warrick, Pamela. "The Fall from Spyglass Hill." ''Los Angeles Times''. 29-04-1998. Retrieved 22-10-2009. Page 3. [http://articles.latimes.com/1998/apr/29/news/ls-45407?pg=3] In 1973, Letourneau's 3-year-old brother drowned in the family pool at their home in the Spyglass Hill section of Corona del Mar, California. In 1982, her father's political career was severely damaged when it was revealed that during his affair with a former student at Santa Ana College, where he had taught political science, he had fathered two children out of wedlock.[http://books.google.com/books?id=ij4Wc-5krxYC&pg=PA122&dq=mary+kay+letourneau&ei=I0kNTO73I5TEygTp9fiBBQ&cd=16#v=onepage&q=mary%20kay%20letourneau&f=false Spin Magazine, June 1998, p 124] Her father's affair caused her parents to separate, but they later reconciled. [http://articles.latimes.com/1998/apr/29/news/ls-45407?pg=4] Mary Kay attended [[Cornelia Connelly High School]], an [[all-girls]] [[Catholic school]] in [[Anaheim, California]], where she was a member of the [[cheerleading]] squad for [[Servite High School]] . During her high school years she is reported to have "liked parties, boys, and traveling."Noe, Denise. ''Mary Kay Letourneau: The Romance that was a Crime''. [http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/criminal_mind/psychology/marykay_letourneau/2.html] She was also a student at [[Arizona State University]] and was reported to be a "party-animal." ==Personal life== While attending Arizona State University, Letourneau, then Schmitz, met and married fellow student Steve Letourneau. They had four children, the first conceived while she was enrolled at Arizona State University.{{Citation needed|date=November 2010}} Letourneau says she was not in love with Steve Letourneau and married him after being urged by her parents. Letourneau and her husband left the universityNoe, Denise. ''Mary Kay Letourneau: The Romance that was a Crime''. From chapter entitled "Marrying Mr. Right Now." [http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/criminal_mind/psychology/marykay_letourneau/4.html] and moved to [[Anchorage, Alaska]].Noe, Denise. ''Mary Kay Letourneau: The Romance that was a Crime''. From chapter entitled "Marrying Mr. Right Now." [http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/criminal_mind/psychology/marykay_letourneau/4.html] Entire work available at truTV.com website, as part of its "Crime Library." After a year in [[Alaska]], her husband was transferred to [[Seattle]] and Letourneau gave birth to her second child, whom she named Claire. Letourneau attended night classes at [[Seattle University]] and graduated in 1989. Later she began teaching second grade at Shorewood Elementary School in the Seattle suburb of [[Burien, Washington]]. Letourneau's marriage reportedly suffered from financial problems and extramarital affairs by both partners. Letourneau's attorney, former neighbor and friend, David Gehrke, says that she was "emotionally and physically abused by her husband" during the marriage and twice "went to the hospital for treatment, and police were called," even though criminal charges were never filed. Despite these marital issues, Letourneau gave birth to two more children, her son Nicholas and her daughter Jacqueline.Warrick, Pamela. "The Fall from Spyglass Hill." ''Los Angeles Times''. 29-04-1998. Retrieved 22-10-2009. Page 3. [http://articles.latimes.com/1998/apr/29/news/ls-45407?pg=6] In May 1999, while incarcerated, Letourneau divorced Steve Letourneau and surrendered custody of her four children.Candy Hatcher, Letourneau can profit from story, appeals court rules [http://www.seattlepi.com/local/mklet19.shtml][[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]]April 19, 2000 Letourneau's brother John Patrick Schmitz is the former deputy counsel to President [[George H. W. Bush]].[http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/washingtonpost/access/66688459.html?dids=66688459:66688459&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Jan+12%2C+2001&author=Adam+Bernstein&pub=The+Washington+Post&desc=Conservative+GOP+Congressman+John+G.+Schmitz%2C+70%2C+Dies&pqatl=google Washington Post, Conservative GOP Congressman] ==Crime, trial and conviction== In 1996 while Letourneau was a Des Moines, Washington elementary school teacher, her relationship with 13-year-old student Vili Fualaau transformed from friendship into flirtation and sex. Letourneau was arrested in March 1997 after her husband, Steve Letourneau, notified the police. During the trial she was examined and diagnosed with manic depression. Letourneau pled guilty and was convicted of two counts of second-degree child rape. She was sentenced to six months in the county jail and three years of treatment.{{Clarify|date=November 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://heinonline.org/HOL/LandingPage?collection=journals&handle=hein.journals/jle35&div=36&id=&page= |title=HeinOnline |publisher=HeinOnline |date= |accessdate=2010-10-03}} At that time she was not required to register as a sex offender. As part of her plea bargain, Letourneau agreed to avoid any further contact with Fualaau. Two weeks (or one month){{Clarify|date=November 2010}} after her release from jail, police found Letourneau while she was having sexual relations with Fualaau in her car. She was arrested for violating the terms of her parole and the police found $6200 in cash and her passport inside her car. As a result, Letourneau was sentenced to seven-and-a-half years in prison. In October 1998, while serving her sentence, Letourneau gave birth to her second daughter by Fualaau. In January, 2001, Letourneau's father died, and she was denied a release from prison to attend his funeral.{{cite web| title = Mary K. Letourneau's father dies; she won't get to attend funeral| url = http://www.seattlepi.com/local/mkay11ww.shtml| work = Local| publisher = [[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]]| date = January 11, 2001| accessdate = May 12, 2009}} While in prison Letourneau tutored fellow inmates, created audio books for blind readers, participated in the prison choir and "rarely missed Mass." Because of her celebrity status Letourneau was unpopular with other inmates, "sassed guards and balked at work" and spent "18 of her first 24 months" in solitary confinement.[http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20150636,00.html Jerome Richard July 26, 2004, Together Again? People (magazine)] In 2002, Fualaau's family sued the Highline School District and the city of [[Des Moines, Washington]], for emotional suffering, lost wages, and the costs of rearing his two children, claiming the school and the Des Moines Police Department had failed to protect him from Letourneau.{{cite web| first = Tracy| last= Johnson| title = Fualaau's suit says he wasn't protected from Letourneau| url = http://www.seattlepi.com/local/63408_mary22.shtml| work = Local| publisher = [[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]]| date = March 22, 2002| accessdate = May 11, 2009}} During the ten week trial, defense attorneys [[Anne Bremner]], representing the Des Moines Police Department, and Michael Patterson, representing the Highline School District, prevailed and no damages were awarded.{{cite web| first = Sam| last = Skolnik| title = Schools, police absolved in Fualaau case| url= http://www.seattlepi.com/local/71277_vili21.shtml| work = Local| publisher = [[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]]| date = May 21, 2002| accessdate = May 11, 2009}} Letourneau was released on a community placement program on August 4, 2004 and the following day she registered with the King County Sheriff's Office as a Level 2 sex offender.{{cite web| first = Sam| last = Skolnik| coauthors = Vanessa Ho| title = Letourneau registers as sex offender| url = http://www.seattlepi.com/local/184960_order05.html| work = Local| publisher = [[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]]| date = August 5, 2004| accessdate = May 11, 2009}} ==Relationship with Vili Fualaau== Letourneau first met Vili Fualaau when he was a student in her second-grade class at Shorewood Elementary School in [[Burien, Washington]];{{cite book|last= Gartner|first= Richard B.|authorlink= Richard Gartner|title= Betrayed as Boys: Psychodynamic Treatment of Sexually Abused Men|url= http://books.google.com/?id=lpfT4zUb2rsC|format= [[Google Book Search]]|accessdate= May 12, 2009|year= 1999|publisher= Guilford Press|location= [[New York City|New York]]|isbn= 9781572306448|oclc= 317520944|id= {{LCCN|98|0|55694}}|page= 45|chapter= Encoding Sexual Abuse as Sexual Initiation|chapterurl= http://books.google.com/books?id=lpfT4zUb2rsC&printsec=frontcover&cad=0#PPA45,M1}} she later taught a sixth-grade class in which Fualaau was a student. Letourneau began an intimate relationship with 12-year-old Fualaau,{{cite web| first = Tatiana | last = Morales| title = What's Next For LeTourneau?| url = http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2004/07/30/earlyshow/living/main633157.shtml| publisher= [[The Early Show]]| date = August 3, 2004| accessdate = June 1, 2009}} and at 35 Letourneau became pregnant with Fualaau's child. Letourneau was subsequently arrested, convicted and imprisoned for [[statutory rape|statutory]] "second degree rape of a child". Letourneau gave birth to two children with Fualaau, giving her a total of six children. Her first daughter with Fualaau, Audrey, was born in May 1997 while Letourneau was out of jail on bail. Daughter Georgia Alexis was conceived while Letourneau was on probation, and was born in October 1998 while Letourneau was incarcerated. After Letourneau's release from prison in 2004, Fualaau, then age 21, filed a motion in court, requesting a reversal of the no-contact order against Letourneau. A few days later the request was granted.{{cite web| title = Letourneau now allowed to see former student| url =http://www.seattlepi.com/local/185267_mary07.html| work = Local| publisher = [[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]]| date = August 7, 2004| accessdate = May 11, 2009}} Letourneau and Fualaau were married on May 20, 2005 in the Seattle suburb of [[Woodinville]] in a ceremony at the [[Columbia Winery]]. Exclusive access to the wedding was given to the television show, ''[[Entertainment Tonight]]'' and photographs were released through other media outlets. Letourneau has said that she would like to have another child and return to the teaching profession{{cite web| title = Letourneau and Fualaau, one year later| url = http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/13064459/| publisher = [[Dateline NBC]]| date = June 2, 2006| accessdate = May 11, 2009}} and indicated that by law she is permitted to teach at private schools and community colleges.{{cite web | title = Letourneau and Fualaau, one year later| url = http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/13064459/| publisher = [[Dateline NBC]]| date = June 2, 2006| accessdate = January 21, 2010}} Since their marriage, Letourneau and Fualaau have hosted three "Hot for Teacher Night" promotions at a Seattle night club with Fualaau serving as the disc jockey and Letourneau as host.[http://www.nyissues.com/mary-kay-letourneau-latest-update-mary-kay-letourneau-wedding.html Mary Kay latest update, NY Issues.com][http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,521139,00.html Mary Kay Hosts, Fox News]{{cite news| title = Letourneau, young spouse to host "Hot for Teacher" night| url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/localnews/2009249390_webletourneau22.html | agency = Associated Press| publisher = The Seattle Times| date = May 21, 2009| accessdate = June 7, 2009}}{{cite web| first = Casey | last = McNerthney| title = Inside the Mary Kay Letourneau "Hot For Teacher" night| url = http://blog.seattlepi.com/thebigblog/archives/169396.asp?source=mypi| work = The Big Blog| publisher = [[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]]| date = May 24, 2009| accessdate = June 7, 2009}} During an ''Inside Edition'' interview Fualaau said, "I'm not a victim. I'm not ashamed of being a father. I'm not ashamed of being in love with Mary Kay."[http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2004/07/30/earlyshow/living/main633157.shtml CBS News: What's Next for LeTuorneau?] Attorney Anne Bremner, who met Letourneau in 2002 during Fualaau's civil suit, said that Letourneau considered her affair with Fualaau to be "eternal and endless."
